1.title: Fire & Blood
1.desc: The first of two volumes (I'll believe it when I see it, George) Fire and Blood tells the story of the Targaryens from Aegon the Conqueror's landing in Westeros through the Dance of the Dragons until Aegon III comes of age. <cite>Fire and Blood</cite> feels encyclopedic. The writing is terse and matter of fact, though Martin's clever prose sneak through. Really, though, this book is just for fans in love with the World of Ice and Fire who crave more epic worldbuilding.

2.title: All Systems Red
2.desc: A fast-paced novella about a Deadpool-esque sentient security robot who, against its best wishes, cares for its human companions as they try to survive on a remote planet where everything is not as it seems. The snarky, first-person narration gives way to a hidden depth about identity and introversion.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

3.title: Berlin, Vol. 1
3.subtitle: City of Stones
3.desc: A beautiful black and white graphic novel set in 1928. <cite>Berlin</cite> follows a wide range of characters, particularly journalist Kurt Severing and artist Marthe Muller, as tempers flare and the world darkens around them. While gorgeous and captivating at times, this felt like a slog in sections, an accomplishment for a 200-page graphic novel.

4.title: Bossypants
4.desc: An uproariously funny memoir of Tina Fey's childhood, early improv comedy career, and commercial successes with SNL and 30 Rock. Organized as a guide to being a successful leader of creative-types, Fey's writing bounces between insightful, reflective, and laugh-out-loud hilarious from one sentence to the next.
tags: Judge this book by it's great cover

5.title: Stories of Your Life and Others
5.desc: While less focused than his second book, <cite>Exhalation</cite>, Chiang's first short story collection is mesmerizing. The first tale, <cite>Tower of Babylon</cite> was his first published story and still managed to win a Hugo. <cite>Stories of Your Life</cite> became the hit-movie <cite>Arrival</cite>. Other pieces explore alternate histories in which scientific discoveries evolved differently. Despite the high-concepts, his stories always feel grounded in human characters entering readers into strange worlds that still somehow feel surprisingly close to the one we inhabit.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

6.title: Talking to Strangers
6.subtitle: What We Should Know About the People We Don’t Know
6.desc: You know his shtick. Take one part social psychology study, another part current event reinterpreted, top it off with a heaping spoonful of rhetorical questions and you've got a Gladwell book. Yet, I can't help but find myself curiosity piqued by the stories and research he juxtaposes in <cite>Talking With Strangers</cite>. Am I always convinced by his conclusions? No. But, this book is by far his most thought provoking for how it frames infamous public figures -- Amanda Knox, Brock Turner, Jerry Sandusky. This stands with <cite>The Tipping Point</cite> as one of his best works.

7.title: In the Garden of Beasts
7.subtitle: Love, Terror, and an American Family in Hitler's Berlin
7.desc: A meticulously researched portrait of a country descending into Nazisms through the eyes of the American ambassador and his family. While the short encounters with Hitler are intensely engaging, all but the most curious World War II buffs will find the rest of this tale a bit slow.

8.title: Home After Dark
8.desc: After his mother's abandonment, Russell and his father pack up the car and make for California, eventually settling in remote Marshfield where Russell is left to fend for himself as he discovers what it means to grow into a young man. While equally beautifully rendered, this work is not up to snuff with Small’s <cite>Stitches</cite>. Though, this book might appeal to graphic novel skeptics looking for more literature and less comic book.

9.title: Exhalation
9.desc: From the author of the short story that became the hit movie <cite>Arrival</cite>, a beautiful, philosophical collection of nine stories exploring time travel, free will, and artificial intelligence. Months later, I am still thinking about these stories and in awe of their creativity and flawless execution.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

10.title: Blood, Sweat, and Pixels
10.subtitle: The Triumphant, Turbulent Stories Behind How Video Games Are Made
10.desc: <cite>Blood, Sweat, and Pixels</cite> is a compelling read for fans of video games. Schreier tells the story of how 10 games -- from triple-A, big budget games like Diablo III to one-person projects like Stardew Valley -- get made (or not) and all of the corporate politics and challenges that get in the way. If you’ve ever wondered how a development team can spend years and millions on a game that is obviously terrible, this book will help you understand.<cite>Blood, Sweat, and Pixels</cite> is a compelling read for fans of video games. Schreier tells the story of how 10 games -- from triple-A, big budget games like Diablo III to one-person projects like Stardew Valley -- get made (or sadly don’t) and all of the corporate politics and challenges that get in the way. If you’ve ever wondered how a development team can spend years and millions on a game that is obviously terrible, this book will help you understand.

11.title: Un-Trumping America
11.subtitle: A Plan to Make America a Democracy Again
11.desc: Much stronger work than his first book, <cite>Yes We (Still) Can</cite>, host of the popular lefty podcast, <cite>Pod Save America</cite>, outlines a vision for how Democrats can regain power in American politics. Mixing media strategy expertise, rants against Paul Ryan, White House experience, and hard-hitting humor, Pfeiffer makes a compelling case for more aggressive tactics by Democrats.

12.title: The Last Wish
12.subtitle: Introducing the Witcher
12.desc: Meet Geralt of a Rivia, a genetically modified monster hunter with a rye wit and reluctant commitment to doing good. This collection of short stories is a great introduction to the world of <cite>The Witcher</cite> that became a smash-hit video game and a Netflix series which plucked many of its plot arcs directly from this work.

13.title: Why We're Polarized
13.desc: I’ve learned more from Ezra Klein and his podcast than perhaps any other person. It is no surprise that Klein has crafted an insightful and original analysis of our current politics. Klein clearly articulates how our identities, once broken into many unrelated parts, have now aligned dramatically at two poles. Weaving in historical research, social psychology, and modern politics, Klein’s new book manages to live up to the promise of its title without retreading the same gut-feeling explanations seen elsewhere.

14.title: The Night Circus
14.desc: A whimsical tale full of magic, mystery, and romance, <cite>The Night Circus</cite> is unlike any other fantasy novel you’ve read. It tells the story of two magicians playing a game they don’t really understand. This novel is packed with curious characters who hold their secrets close until the very end.

15.title: Daytripper
15.desc: <cite>Daytripper</cite> visits alternate realities of Bras de Olivias Dominguez’s life. Each chapter is a what-if, exploring the spiraling, haunting repercussions of the choices we all make each day.

16.title: Light of the Stars
16.subtitle: Alien Worlds and the Fate of the Earth
16.desc: There are 40 billion habitable planets in the Milky Way, our local galaxy. If only 0.01 percent of those planets have intelligent life, there should be 4 million intelligent civilizations in our galaxy alone. So, where is everybody? This is the Fermi paradox, the crucial idea driving research into extraterrestrial life. Frank’s book serves as a history of the study of aliens, from ancient Greece to modern day. While enjoyable for those already curious about the subject, this is not the most captivating account of the supremely interesting subject.

17.title: Blindspot
17.subtitle: Hidden Biases of Good People
17.desc: Your mind does not work the way you think. Most of your brain’s labor is subconscious, hidden, and mysterious. We all accept that our brain pumps our blood and blinks our eyes without conscious thought, but we underestimate the power our subconscious has over our opinions and impulses. The magic of this book is the collection of simple experiments you can try that make the power of your subconscious visible. <cite>Blind Spot</cite> provides indisputable evidence of your implicit biases but is perhaps a bit too much review for those who have taken a collegiate psychology class.

18.title: Nimona
18.desc: I’ve never been so quickly and thoroughly charmed as I was by <cite>Nimona</cite>. What begins as a cute story about a shapeshifter who latches on as a villain's sidekick quickly grows into a beautiful story of identity, distorting genre tropes over and again. I love this book.

19.title: The Color of Magic
19.desc: The first novel in a 70+ book collection in the Discworld setting by Terry Pratchett, <cite>The Color of Magic</cite> is a charming, messy novel. Much of the story drags but there are epic moments of world building -- like a civilization that walks on the ceiling using mounted rings and hooked shoes -- as well as Pratchett’s effervescent humor. I didn’t particularly take to this book, but I put it down eager to read of Sir Terry’s work in the future.

20.title: The Storm Whale
20.desc: Noi is lonely when his father is away fishing all day. So, when a whale washes up on the beach near his home, he does the only reasonable thing and brings it home to his bathtub. With gorgeous art and a tale that will tug on your heartstrings, <cite>The Storm Whale</cite> is a must share with preschoolers.
tags: Judge this book by it's great cover

21.title: Has Anyone Seen the President?
21.desc: Reading his article from <cite>Bloomberg View</cite>, Lewis paints a vivid (and terrifying) portrait of the populist politics of Trump and Bannon. For those unfamiliar with Lewis’ work, this short audiobook gives you a taste of his incredible ability to weave stories together. He has many better works, but this one is fascinating for the authentic window into the mind of Steve Bannon.

22.title: Dear Girls
22.subtitle: Intimate Tales, Untold Secrets, & Advice for Living Your Best Life
22.desc: Ali Wong’s two Netflix Comedy Specials are among the funniest things I have experienced -- no doubt influenced by recently becoming a parent. So, I had high, probably unfair, expectations for Wong’s first book, <cite>Dear Girls</cite>. While it didn’t live up to my expectations, there were still many laugh-out-loud moments, particularly in her descriptions of her early comedy career in New York. Wong fans will likely enjoy this, but just don’t expect a book version of her stand up specials.

23.title: The Encyclopedia of Early Earth
23.desc: I’ve been staring at a blank page for a few minutes now trying to decide how to explain <cite>The Encyclopedia of Early Earth</cite>. It’s an allegory. A love story. A fable. A fantasy novel. Except it’s not really any of those things. Following a young man who strikes out from his home at the north pole, the story feels like a Greek epic poem rendered in cute and stunning art. None of this sounds like it should work. But, it does. It really does.

24.title: Giraffes Can't Dance
24.desc: <cite>Giraffes Can’t Dance</cite> is a charming, poetic storybook about poor Gerald, a giraffe who’s told he can’t dance by all of the other animals of the jungle. While a little long for the youngest kids, your two- and three-year olds will appreciate the images of the lions and rhinos tangoing and boogying on the dance floor.

25.title: You Have Arrived at Your Destination
25.desc: Towles short story, <cite>You Have Arrived at your Destination</cite>, is part of the Forward Collection of science fiction short stories organized by Blake Crouch and, unfortunately, only available on Kindle and Audible. Towles' story explores the near future in which parents can see their child’s future before they are born and select a fetus with the life they want. High in concept, but a bit short to really explore it, <cite>You Have Arrived at your Destination</cite> asks big questions but stops short of investigating them in a way that is satisfying.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

26.title: Caffeine
26.subtitle: How Caffeine Created the Modern World
26.desc: The famous food and drug writer tackles caffeine in this just-for-audible audiobook. With his usual mix of curiosity, clever writing, and self-experimentation, Pollan shares how coffee (really its psychoactive compounds) spread across the world from the Middle East and revolutionized society all the while sharing his personal experience of giving up his daily dose (or doses) of the drug.

27.title: Artificial Condition
27.desc: Picking up right where <cite>All Systems Red</cite> left off, <cite>Artificial Condition</cite> shares the same snarky thriller vibe of the first book in the series. Yet this book lacks a little of its predecessor’s magic with the exception of Murderbot’s new overbearing, obsessive AI friend. If you loved book one, you’ll enjoy this too. But, there’s not much new to be discovered here.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

28.title: Winners Take All
28.subtitle: The Elite Charade of Changing the World
28.desc: In the 2016 and 2020 Democratic Primary campaigns, Bernie Sanders routinely described the US’s economic systems as rigged for Wall Street and top 1%. Anand Giridharadas’ <cite>Winners Take All</cite> fills in the details of Sander’s message, persuasively explaining how the wealthy manage to hold onto power while still claiming to change the world. Taking a sharp aim at philanthropists and professional Ted-talkers, Giridharadas pushes back against the individual-blaming and privatized solutions to societal challenges, advocating instead for a recommitment to political and public approaches.

29.title: Born a Crime
29.subtitle: Stories From a South African Childhood
29.desc: Trevor Noah’s hilarious and insightful memoir, <cite>Born a Crime</cite>, is chock full of moving and often hilarious stories of a childhood in apartheid South Africa. Noah, the host of The Daily Show, lends his voice to the audiobook, moving in-and-out of a multitude of South African languages and accents. His performance makes this story a must-listen. This book is not just funny, it’s instructive, painting a detailed portrait of the culture and poverty of the region in the ‘80s and ‘90s.

30.title: The Education of an Idealist
30.subtitle: A Memoir
30.desc: Samantha Power’s moving memoir traces the arc of her life from war correspondent, to Pulitzer Prize winning author, Obama aid, and United Nations Ambassador as she wrestles with how to prevent mass atrocities and genocide acroos the globe. As Power transitions from outspoken critic of the US government to policy maker, she wrestles with how to affect the change she so desperately wants, shedding light on how and why it is often so hard for the governments to do the right thing.

31.title: Magic for Liars
31.desc: <cite>Magic for Liars</cite> is the unlikely mashup of Harry Potter, Mean Girls, and a noir detective mystery. The results is the gripping tale of PI Ivy Gamble's attempt to solve a murder at a high school for magic users. With engaging characters and twists around every corner, I wasn't able to put this one down.
tags: Judge this book by it's great cover

32.title: Wool
32.desc: You must read Wool. That's all you need to know. Frankly, the less you know about this book (really a collection of self-published sequential short stories) the better. Howey has crafted a post-apocalyptic thriller with human characters and so many twists there is no way you will be able to put this down.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

33.title: The Right Stuff
33.desc: Tom Wolfe’s incredibly written <cite>The Right Stuff</cite> explores the culture of test pilots in the early stages of the space program. The book is at once insightful, hilarious, biting, and captivating as he explores what in god’s name would make a man volunteer to be strapped to an untested missile and blasted into space. The Audible version with narration by Dennis Quaid whose performance and Texan drawl is the perfect compliment to Wolfe’s writing.
tags: Judge this book by it's great cover

34.title: The Power
34.desc: Like all great science fiction, <cite>The Power</cite> is more about the real world than the fantasy world it portrays. Alderman’s novel follows four characters as women suddenly develop the ability to deliver electric shocks through their hands, making them the physically dominate sex. Shocking and insightful, this was instantly one of my all-time favorite works of science fiction.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

35.title: Recursion
35.desc: What begins with a cop investigating a mysterious disease that causes false memories evolves into a mind-bending, time-travel thriller. Crouch is a master of the sci-fi thriller and this, his best work, sucks you right down the rabbit hole.
tags: Where we're going we don't need roads

36.title: Limits of the Known
36.desc: After a lifetime spent documenting adventurers, Roberts reflects on what makes some seek out the dangerous and extreme. The histories of mountaineering, first contact, arctic exploration, and cave diving are fascinating on their own, but the magic of <cite>Limits of the Known</cite> is the way in which Roberts weaves his own adventures and experiences into these stories. This book will overwhelm you with the power of its prose and meditations on what it means to live.

37.title: The Rabbit Listened
37.desc: Doerrfeld’s <cite>The Rabbit Listened</cite> is a beautiful story about how to support someone who is grieving. When Taylor’s huge block sculpture is suddenly destroyed, a parade of animals visit try their best to ease the pain in their own way. The chicken wants to talk, the bear wants to shout, and the snake wants to destroy someone else’s tower, but only the rabbit knows that Taylor just needs someone to listen.
